content.description: Mantel a protruding triangular block. Move right and gain a finger crack on a sloped ledge. Mantel the ledge and walk the finger crack to a pillar. Climb the pillar for a dramatic finish and find an anchor crack among the boulders.
content.protection: The first mantel can be protected, but there is ground fall potential when clipping your second piece. There are no pieces on the pillar, but the climbing is easier than 5.5 and very secure. Gear to 0.75"
content.location: Across the road from the Otter Cliff parking lot, follow the path to a lookout. Trend right and go towards the ocean. The cliff has an upper and lower tier, and you will be on the upper tier. Descend to the lower tier by a fourth class down climb through a v notch or rappel. Once down, look right for an obvious large, sloping ledge. The start of the climb is under the ledge.

content.description: A great small face with fun climbing and excellent pro. Start on a step in a large crack and work your way up the face. There are a few possible lines, but the central one seems about 5.6. After topping out, you can build an anchor in a crack and boulder about 15' uphill.
content.location: Across the road from the parking for Otter Cliffs, follow the path to a lookout. If you veer right and continue towards the ocean from the lookout, you will be near the topout of the climb. The start of the climb is on the lower tier of the cliff. To get there, you can take a fourth class downclimb through a v notch and a jumble of boulders, or you can rap down. Once down, look for a vertical wall with a crack system. There is a distinctive step at the base.

content.description: Generally less crowded than Otter Cliffs, there are a variety of smaller climbs. I am looking for information on these climbs. If anyone has the names for them, or any other info, I would be happy to add it.
